Basta Ya! Unidos Por El Cambio!
(Enough! Unite For Change!)

I am sitting under this sign and a massive American flag in the Obama campaign office in Coral Gables, Miami. I have just flown in from New York to volunteer for Obama in Florida till election day.

At this stage all activity is concentrated on GOTV: Getting Out The Vote. This translates into hours spent driving from house to house making sure that those who say they will vote for Obama actually do. Early voting is already underway in Miami with long waiting times.

Early voting counts from ballots already cast at the polls and through the mail are favouring Obama with a 166,311-vote lead. But there is still a lot of work to be done. Some polls are giving Obama a four-point lead while others are predicting that it is too close to call. Both Florida and Miami Dade county, in which this office is located, are up for grabs. As the election nears, anti-Obama groups are getting more vocal.

This morning I arrived at the campaign office to catch a noisy protest by anti-abortion Cuban Catholics. Ten women holding graphic pictures of fetuses with the words "Voting for Obama is Voting for Dead Babies". And one man looking rather dapper in a grey suit thumbing a rosary with one hand and holding up a sign with the other: "Chávez. Lula. Ortega. Castro. The Community party USA: All Are Backing Obama. Want To Join Them?" The sign and the rosary make good TV. And sure enough, a TV camera crew has shown up.

But is this what the majority of the Cuban community thinks? It is hard to tell. I head down to Little Havana to take a stroll down Calle Ocho, its main drag. It's a gateway to a very different Miami to that of the much-photographed South Beach glitz and glamour: lots of 99 cents shops and old men strolling or playing dominoes, the smell of cigars drifting around corners, salsa and merengue blaring out of rundown cafes.

McCain-Palin signs are stapled onto palm trees and being held up by a women standing at an intersection. I go into a cigar place to try and guage the atmosphere. There are rows and rows of cigars from Nicaragua, Honduras, Dominica, plus the ones hand-rolled in the factory around the block. The conversation with the shop owner doesn't get very far. She supports Obama but as I don't speak enough Spanish to ask why, and she doesn't speak English, it has to end there.

Next stop, a Cuban Creole restaurant: same story there. I do notice that everything on the menu is Cuban with the exception of one item which is decidedly American – racion de papas fritas: freedom fries. Perhaps that says enough.

Back at the campaign office, a staffer tells me that this year has seen a significant jump in Cuban Democrats in Miami. This in addition to the high black turnout that is expected might balance out the people worried about Communism and abortion. That in addition to the few Creole speakers I met sporting Obama signs saying "Chanjman: Nou Bezwen" (Change We Can Believe In).

It is now 10.30pm and someone is playing salsa on their laptop and another guy is singing along as he ploughs through his data entry tasks for the evening. "I have faith in Americans, I really do. The majority of them anyway," I hear a volunteer say, to no one in particular. Fingers crossed her faith will be rewarded.

Barack Obama once dressed up as a pirate. (That's him, on the left.) These days, though, he's older and wiser, so tonight he'll dress up as a pumpkin instead. As what are you dressing up tonight? Not a bad imitation of Sarah Palin, hopefully. Or maybe you are British and will stay at home, in your normal clothes.

John McCain will be on Saturday Night Live this weekend. Is this the early-November surprise? In the past, don't forget, he has performed a Barbra Streisand medley on the show. Could that be what the undecideds have been waiting for? [Associated Press]

Hillary Clinton's former spokesman, Phil Singer, regrets that her campaign was so unremittingly obnoxious to the press. "I yelled at more reporters than I ever dreamed I'd yell at," he says. "Honestly, I deeply regret it because not only was it wrong, but it got in the way, it made me less effective." [Politics Magazine]

Slate founder Michael Kinsley almost didn't have his vote counted because the signature on his postal ballot didn't match that on his registration -- a little-known requirement that could cost some people their votes. [Seattle Weekly]

A big Washington Post profile of John McCain's "chief loyalist" and alter ego, Mark Salter, the man who has been instrumental in crafting the senator's image, and who's now in a dark, exhausted mood about what he perceives as having been across-the-board pro-Obama media bias for the duration of the campaign. Republican recriminations have begun in earnest. Looking forward to senator John McCain's near certain defeat in the US presidential elections, opposing factions of the GOP are busy crafting narratives to explain the loss that pin the blame squarely on those other ne'er-do-wells in the party.

"If you believe in miracles, you still believe in McCain," said Republican consultant Joe Gaylord. The AP correctly characterised him as only one member of a "mounting chorus of Republicans predicting their nominee's demise". That chorus is mounting because, less than a week out, McCain trails in polls in several must-win states.

Quite a few explanations for this impending electoral Armageddon are at least plausible. President George Bush is currently less popular than a bad hangover, which makes him a truly tough act for any Republican to follow. Nobody wins them all and the economy has gone sour at a particularly bad time for the party in the White House.

But all of the explanations for an Obama administration without a villain or a goat in them rather miss the point. Republicans are looking for someone to blame for their unpopularity. And it would be much easier if that person's mistakes and shortcomings reaffirmed their preconceived notions of how the world works.

Smart operators are getting an early start because they know competing narratives about the loss will help determine the future of the party. Those narratives are 1) "Sarah Palin lost it for us" or b) "McCain's bailout theatrics lost it for us". The contest now is to make one of those stories stick.

The Blame Palin faction has a head start. She is roundly hated by the more moderate-liberal wing of the party. They are less numerous but well connected and overrepresented among journalists and pundits.

Pro-war left libertarian author Ryan Sager wrote that the pick "complete[d] the transformation of the GOP into a southern-centered party based on social division and cultural resentment". In a widely publicised interview, New York Times columnist David Brooks said that Palin represented a "fatal cancer to the Republican Party" because she comes from a "populist tradition" of conservatism that not only "scorn[s] liberal ideas but … scorn[s] ideas entirely".

The story that anti-Palinites tell is one of honor and decency wasted. With his record of military service, bipartisanship and thinking outside the box, McCain could have appealed to most voters of intelligence and goodwill. Then he picked the untested Alaska governor in a naked grab for votes, and it backfired. It caused many undecided voters to think of McCain not as a stand-up guy but as an crass opportunist given to the worst sort of pandering, and thus rejected him.

The only problem with this story is what it leaves out. On the eve of the Palin nomination, McCain was dead in the political water. Conservatives didn't like him. He was too old and too rigid. Barack Obama had just delivered a convention speech in a sports arena that shattered previous records of television viewership for convention speeches.

Then McCain picked the little-known northernmost governor to be his running mate and bought himself a fighting chance. There was a real possibility that many grassroots conservatives would bolt and vote for Libertarian candidate Bob Barr. Palin brought them back into the fold while generating intense media interest. A week after Obama delivered his record breaking speech, McCain topped it.

It looked for a brief moment like Palin had given McCain the edge. So it is not at all surprising that many conservatives are reacting badly to criticism of the Alaska governor. Former White House aide Jim Nuzzo told the Sunday Telegraph that following the election "A lot of people are going to be excommunicated. David Brooks and [fellow anti-Palinites] David Frum and Peggy Noonan are dead people in the Republican Party".

Then there's the bizarre bail-out behaviour explanation. The Arizona senator announced that he was suspending his campaign to return to DC to deal with the serious problem of crafting a government bail-out, and thus would be skipping the first presidential debate. Instead, he put in a few more media appearances, returned to DC and almost derailed bail-out talks, then took part in the first debate anyway. He insisted that the fundamentals of the American economy were "sound," railed against Wall Street and called for the replacement of the current head of the SEC with New York Democratic Attorney General Andrew Cuomo.

Conservative House Republicans worked to vote down the first bail-out bill. McCain never showed any interest in opposing it. He went along with the Senate bill, which was loaded down with the sort of ridiculous pork projects that he regularly rails against, and he even proposed to enlarge the scope of the bail-out by using the government to restructure mortgages for homeowners who felt they'd got a bad deal. Most voters likely found this weird. Conservatives found it depressing. It reaffirmed every doubt they'd ever had about McCain's vision of the economy and, according to their favoured story, only hastened his defeat.

They're right that McCain had made gains running as a born again conservative and faltered during the bail-out, but there's an awful lot of static in the polling. The stock market tanked and the nation was treated to dour economic forecasts. McCain might have opposed the bail-out but taken a beating anyway. We'll never know for sure, though it would have been nice for Americans to have had a clear cut choice on this important issue.

In the Republican recriminations, shots at Palin traded with shots at the man who chose to put her on the ticket, we are seeing the Dougherty Doctrine in all its ugly glory. As the wag wrote, "If it were more like me, the Republican Party would be better off. It's failing because it's like you".

In the waning days of the election, the McCain campaign has realised that its attempts to tie Barack Obama to "unrepentant domestic terrorist" Bill Ayers aren't having much effect. So it's trying a new tactic, blasting the candidate for consorting with unrepentant domestic Palestinian Rashid Khalidi. Now an eminent professor of Arab studies at Columbia, Khalidi, like Obama, formerly taught at the University of Chicago, where the two men were friends. Hoping to instill shadowy associations between Obama and Arabs in the minds of low-information voters, the McCain team has taken to slandering a thoughtful and respectable man.
The McCain team is now demanding that the Los Angeles Times release a tape of Obama's appearance at a 2003 going-away party for Khalidi. The Times is refusing to do so because, when it was given the video, it agreed not to share it. Playing the aggrieved victim, McCain said in a radio interview: "If there was a tape of John McCain in a neo-Nazi outfit, I think the treatment of the issue would be slightly different." Appearing on CNN yesterday, McCain flack Michael Goldfarb claimed: "Barack Obama has a long track record of being around anti-Semitic, anti-Israel and anti-American rhetoric." Attempting to challenge Goldfarb, CNN host Rick Sanchez said: "Can you name one other person besides Khalidi who he hangs around with who is anti-Semitic?" Goldfarb couldn't, but the damage had been done – not to Obama, but to Khalidi, whose anti-Semitism had been presented as a matter of accepted fact.
I don't know Khalidi personally, though I've interviewed him on a number of occasions and have read his recent book, Resurrecting Empire. I know, however, that there is nothing in his record to justify smearing him as a bigot. While the McCain campaign has presented him as a "PLO spokesman" – and it wouldn't be a crime if he were – in fact, Khalidi was simply an outside adviser to the Palestinian delegation at negotiations convened by the Republican secretary of state James Baker during the first Bush administration. Apparently, McCain is now so hostile to diplomacy that participating in American-sponsored talks is deemed anti-American.
To be sure, Khalidi is a supporter of Palestinian rights and a serious critic of Israel and of American policy in the Middle East, one who is well to the left of Obama. But he condemns violence, criticised Yasser Arafat's corruption and cronyism and has consistently acknowledged Jewish suffering. Fair-minded friends of Israel have praised his writing. New York Times columnist Thomas Friedman, certainly not a notorious Jew-hater, described Under Siege, Khalidi's book about PLO decision-making during the 1982 Lebanon war, as "extremely valuable" and "generally objective, lucid and incisive". Professor Khalidi is on the board of sponsors of the Palestine-Israel Journal, a publication founded by prominent Palestinian and Israeli journalists to encourage dialogue between the two sides. The board also includes famed Israeli writer David Grossman. By the degraded standards of the McCain-Palin campaign, Grossman could also be defamed as an enemy of the Jews. Indeed, so could McCain himself. As has now been widely reported, under McCain's leadership, the International Republican Institute gave nearly half a million dollars to a Palestinian research centre Khalidi co-founded.
The McCain campaign's attacks on Khalidi are categorically different than its attacks on Ayers. Those were unfair to Obama, who was not, by all accounts, particularly close to the man, and who never gave a hint of condoning his youthful violence. Ayers, however, has indeed done shameful things, so his public excoriation was not entirely undeserved. That's not true of Khalidi. He is guilty of nothing. The dangerous implications of McCain's assaults on him stretch beyond this election, suggesting that friendship with prominent Arabs is grounds for suspicion, and thus dangerous for ambitious politicians. (That is, unless the Arabs in question belong to the Saudi royal family). Given that our leaders' failure to even try and understand Arab grievances has contributed to catastrophic foreign policy blunders, Obama's engagement with a prominent, moderate Palestinian intellectual should, in any rational society, be seen as a point in his favour. By trying to turn their acquaintance into evidence of subversion, McCain does more than further disgrace himself. His reckless rhetoric threatens to push legitimate criticism of Israeli and American policy even further outside the bounds of acceptable political discussion, making straight talk on the Middle East ever more elusive.

Politics in the morning paper is nothing new in America - but days before the election, ideologically charged content being packaged with newspapers is sparking a heated debate over advertising standards.
Subscribers to the Cincinnati Enquirer, in the swing state of Ohio, today joined readers in Cleveland and Las Vegas as the latest to get a free add-on with their newspaper: a DVD of an anti-Barack Obama film. The Democrat's supporters, predictably, were displeased.

One newspaper subscriber in Cleveland accused John McCain of funding the DVD advert. "I think it's very sleazy," Marilyn Garfunkel told the local Fox TV network. "I think it does not bode well for them in terms of how they've approached the campaign up to this point."

But the free film, titled Hype: The Obama Effect, was unconnected to the McCain camp. A conservative activist group, Citizens United, is spending more than $1m to distribute 1.25m copies of the Hype DVDs in three election-year battleground states.

The 95-minute film features several attacks on Obama that have been discredited by independent fact-checkers, including a claim that he would raise taxes on most US small businesses. Jerome Corsi, the author of a controversial book criticising Obama, also appears in the film.

Another free advertising DVD, however, has elicited a bigger backlash in this highly contentious election year. A non-profit group called the Clarion Fund has paid for 28m newspaper readers in swing states to receive free copies of Obsession, a film that has drawn criticism from religion scholars for its comparison of radical Islam to Nazism.

Obsession uses stark imagery to create a frightening picture of violence-seeking Muslim extremists. Although the film includes no overtly election-related content, the Clarion's website contained language praising John McCain before later being removed.

As Obsession DVDs appeared on the front steps of news subscribers across the US, a wave of protest developed in response. About 75 readers marched in front of the Oregonian newspaper's offices in Portland, where the mayor had advised against promoting the film.

The News & Observer in Raleigh, North Carolina, drew attention to the DVD advert with an accompanying article and was met with a torrent of response that leaned towards angry criticism of the film. About 50 readers cancelled their subscriptions to the newspaper, according to the Associated Press.

"I do not appreciate this right-wing propaganda being put in this battleground state's newspaper. I find that appalling," one commenter on the News & Observer website wrote.

Another offered sarcastic hope that the newspaper "made a small fortune in distributing this abomination to your subscribers because, in all other ways, your newspaper is totally and irreversibly bankrupt".

Kelly McBride, leader of the ethics faculty at the Poynter Institute of Journalism in Florida, said that the anticipated reader frustration was not reason enough for newspapers to decline the Obsession advert.

"As long as it's clearly labelled as advertising, then I don't think you have grounds to reject it," McBride said. "I don't think you can create a different standard for political adverts than other adverts … The standard is, if you can pay, and it's legal and not grossly offensive to the community, then we'll take it."

The timing of the Obsession mailings, during a hotly contested election as Republicans criticise Obama for pursuing talks with Iran, has raised questions about whether the DVDs were intended to help McCain. The Republican Jewish Coalition, which has endorsed McCain, also has distributed free copies of the film to its members.

Newspapers in Cleveland, Detroit, St Louis, and Greensboro, North Carolina, were among the few that declined to run the Obsession DVD.

"Clarion was thinking of more creative ways to use newspapers than newspapers were," Seth Hettena, a reporter who investigated the film for the Columbia Journalism Review, said.

Hettena described the free DVDs as "fall[ing] into a grey area, at the very least". He cited the timing of the newspaper adverts, their distribution to 14 US states where voters are split on the presidential race, and Clarion's ability to keep its donors secret under the tax laws.

The two films have generated fresh scrutiny of media advertising standards, but DVD inserts are not the only paid content being questioned by readers and journalists alike. Two newspapers in Virginia this week rejected a bid by the National Rifle Association to package their daily editions in plastic bags with the potent message, "Vote for Freedom … Defeat Obama".

We're in the last few days before the election, and we're already getting a sense of what is working and not working for the candidates. The big question at this late hour is whether John McCain can find a message that will persuade undecided voters to break his way in large enough numbers to win.

Part of this post is motived by a question from our election Facebook group. Many people are asking if the Obama half-hour infomercial worked. Mike Mullane asked:

How many people watched the whole half hour? Did any of the papers run instant polls? What was your gut feeling about the Obama ad - was it a mistake? What are the bloggers saying?

Nielsen Media Research which provides the ratings doesn't say whether people watched the entire half hour, but we do know that the Obama-mercial was more popular than some of the regular programming on broadcast networks at the same time. On NBC, that might be down to the new Knight Rider being such a complete waste of time. But 33.5m people, more than 20% in most major TV markets, watched all or part of the infomerical, which is about half the number who watched the debates.

By and large, the media gushed about it. ABC's George Stephanopoulos said it was "worth every penny", which was about the most negative thing he said about it.

I've yet to find a newspaper that ran a snap poll on it. It would be expensive, an expense that most US newspapers can't afford right now, to run a snap poll just looking at an ad, even one at that length. And half-hour ads are not unprecedented in American politics. Billionaire Ross Perot ran 15 infomercials in 1992.

That leaves us to ask whether we're seeing any polls nationally or on the state level show a shift one way or another that might indicate an impact. Some 36 hours later, nationally, apart from a few outliers that show the race tightening quite dramatically, there hasn't been much movement in the polls for weeks. On the state level, there is a little movement, and most of it is not in the direction that benefits John McCain. I'll take a closer look at some of the polls later in the day. They are coming so quickly right now that it takes some effort to find the signal in the noise. I tend to discount national polls at this point and focus on the state polls.

Also one thing to watch in these polls is whether they rely on a voter turnout model from four years ago or are based on "intention to vote". Larry Sabato thinks we're going to break the 1960 "modern high water mark for voter turnout" with more than 60% of potential voters going to the polls.

My gut feeling is that as long as it didn't knock off the air the favourite show of a lot of undecided voters, the impact will be negligible. I doubt it persuaded many people who hadn't already made up their minds. The two potential returns on Obama's $4m investement are making sure that his supporters don't get complacent and fail to vote and that it displaced coverage of McCain for another 24-hour news cycle.

What are bloggers saying? From the great state of Alaska, the blogger behind Own the Sidewalk reports:

After I voted, I stopped by my bank and mentioned to the teller that I'd just voted. So had she. She told me she's been a Republican all her life but just couldn't bring herself to vote for McCain and Palin. After watching the "infomercial," she and her husband had decided to vote for Obama.

One voter does not a wave make, but the number of Republicans who I've met who are voting for Obama this year, sometimes voting for a Democrat for the first time in their lives, shows that this isn't an isolated case.

Conservative blogger Ed Morrissey dismissed the half-hour infomercial as a flop. He does make a good point. The 21.7% figure is combined across five networks, but seeing as it was beating the regular programming on the broadcast networks adds counter-balancing context to that figure.

As I said, the infomercial won't have changed minds, especially in the US political blogosphere where people tend not to sit on the fence. The infomercial should be seen in the context of Obama'a Powell doctrine campaign of totally overwhelming McCain on every level. Obama is drowning out McCain on the air. Obama and his army of paid and volunteer staff dwarf even the vaunted 72-hour GOTV (get out the vote) effort that George Bush orchestrated in 2000 and 2004. Obama is forcing McCain to make tough choices, including pulling money out of GOTV efforts to counter Obama's advantage in advertising.

Joe the Plumber argument not working

While the informercial was an expensive (albeit affordable for Team Obama) wash, McCain's "Joe the Plumber" tax argument doesn't seem to be winning over undecided voters. Brian Schaffner at Pollster.com looks at the numbers and explains why. John McCain is treading on 'dangerous ground when he criticises Obama for wanting to raise taxes on wealthier Americans, and Brian says:

Another problem with using "Joe the Plumber" to criticize the redistribution of wealth is that this argument doesn't seem to have any particular appeal for the demographic "Joe the Plumber" is supposed to represent--working class whites.

John McCain is facing a tough fight to the close. He's having to make difficult decisions with limited resources. Barack Obama's decision not to accept public campaign financing, which would have put his campaign on par financially with John McCain, might have been a broken promise, but it's allowed the Obama to completely overwhelm McCain on almost every level. Public financing of presidential campaigns will have to be overhauled to remain relevant after this election.

Thanks for the question Mike. Keep them coming. If you've got a question, leave them in the comments. I'll try to answer as many as possible in the closing days of this election.

There is a lot of talk about talk with the Taliban in the air. From Washington, London, Peshawar, Kabul, Islamabad and Mecca over the past three weeks we have had news reports on "contacts" between Taliban, Afghan, Pakistani and US representatives about a negotiated solution for the fighting in Afghanistan.

Most sources agree that these amount to little more than "putting out feelers", "testing the water", and "making contacts". In diplomatic-speak this activity appears have the urgency for which the Spanish concept of mañana would be an exaggeration.

For what are the talks aimed at, what kind of Afghanistan do they hope to achieve and in what time-frame? And where's the plan, the strategy, to get this?

This appears to have been the message at a forum convened at the Army and Navy Club close to the White House two weeks ago – details of which have just emerged this morning in the New York Times. Delegates included Kai Eide, the UN Special representative in Kabul, and the former US commander in Afghanistan, General Karl Eikenberry. For two days they briefed security advisers to Barak Obama and John McCain.

Their message was blunt: whoever is sworn in as the next president on January 20 next must have a clear plan for Afghanistan will be too late as security through key parts of the country continues to "spiral down".

The new American Central Command chief, General David Petraeus, has proposed a surge of a further 20,000 American troops, hoping that will fix security in Afghanistan as he says his surge of 35,000 extra forces did in Iraq last year.

But Afghanistan is a whole different tactical ball game from Iraq, from terrain to enemy strengths and tactics and the abilities of the host government forces. The famous Petraeus surge trick may not work twice.

On Tuesday this week the Foreign Secretary David Miliband and the new Defence Secretary John Hutton, flanked by advisers, discussed Iraq and Afghanistan before the combined defence and foreign affairs committees of the House of Commons for some two and a half hours.

The testimony was precise and detailed, but in the end amounted to little more than wondering out loud.

They speculated about the outcomes of the three elections next year in both countries. They wondered what the shape of future governance in Kabul might be. They pondered how to tackle the narco-crime-terrorist economy. There were dark mutterings about Pakistan. This included a wonderful bit of wishful thinking about "getting the Pakistan army to concentrate on the battle for Afghanistan, and not their preoccupation with India". One wonders what particular planet the policy advisers at the FCO and MoD were on when they came up with that line.

The day after, Wednesday, the MoD announced an emergency £700m package to buy a range of 700 new vehicles designed to resist the new generation of mines and remotely triggered bombs being used by the Taliban. These include mine removers, armoured diggers, recce vehicles, personnel and ammunition carriers. The Americans are placing a similar order with Oshkosh and Force Protection for mine-resistant vehicles.

The sense of strategy for both Iraq and Afghanistan is in danger of being lost in an ocean of tactical ideas and initiatives. To say we are going to stick it out, and hope to grind down the Taliban over the next 10 years is not a realistic strategic goal. After all, look at what has been achieved by the internationals in Afghanistan in the seven years since November 2001. (While there have been some gains socially, in health and education, security and the narco-economy must be put in the loss columns of the ledger).

This week Henry Kissinger offered some pithy thoughts about the Vietnam saga, which should provide food for thought for the new US president. Critiquing the reflections of McGeorge Bundy, Kennedy's National Security Adviser, prepared by his researcher, and now critic, Gordon M Goldstein, Kissinger gave these thoughts: "The purpose of war is victory. Stalemate is ... not a desirable strategic objective. Victory needs to be defined as an outcome achievable in a timeframe sustainable by American public opinion."

All very well to have such 20-20 hindsight now, you may argue. However, Kissinger's warning about time in such conflicts is – pardon the pun – timely for what is now happening in Iraq and Afghanistan. Time is running out for the US and its allies in both countries – as the status of forces wrangle is proving in Iraq. You cannot talk about "generational wars" and "open-ended commitments" to seeing it through. You cannot say your forces can be squatters in these lands, when international law and diplomacy, and lore of the insurgents, does not recognise international squatters' rights.

Few people have been more persona non grata than George Bush during this election season. Republican candidates have gone out of their way to avoid being seen with the president. In fact, Bush has raised $40m less for the Republican party and its candidates in the 2008 election than he did last cycle. However, John McCain is becoming equally as toxic. He is, in fact, becoming the next George Bush.

In recent months, McCain has made a particular effort to separate himself from the president and shrug off the liberal talking point that his policies would represent Bush's third term. In September, McCain campaign chief Rick Davis gave Bloomberg News an "emphatic no" when asked whether the two men would be campaigning together this fall, saying that they had "turned that page". (This attitude is a far cry from what McCain said about Bush last February: "I'd be honoured to be anywhere with him under any circumstances.")

Nevertheless, even solid Republicans are now equating McCain with Bush. Norm Coleman, facing a tough Senate re-election race in Minnesota, never mentioned McCain at multiple campaign stops. Last month, an aide to Coleman refused to back McCain's healthcare plan, curiously saying only that Coleman was "aligned with senator Coleman's plan". He also called for the McCain campaign to stop its negative robocalls.

At least two other Republicans, Gordon Smith of Oregon and Susan Collins of Maine, also broke rank and joined the anti-robocall chorus. Smith has gone even further, grabbing hold of Barack Obama's coattails and going out of his way to praise the Democratic candidate.

Republican senatorial committee chairman John Ensign of Nevada recently told MSNBC that there was "no question the top of the ticket is affecting our Senate races, and it's making it a lot more difficult." Senate minority leader Mitch McConnell, in a tight re-election race in Kentucky, hasn't done any events with McCain since a fundraiser last spring.

Few Republicans have come out excited by the direction McCain is taking the party. In fact, the Republican National Committee's website currently has no mentions of McCain on its front page. Obama's name, however, appears five times. The top landing graphic links to a speech by former senator Fred Thompson. (The graphic does eventually change to a McCain promotion, but you have to wait around more than 10 seconds.)

Many conservatives already view their presidential candidate as a lame duck. According to Politico's Jonathan Martin, a "who's who of conservative leaders" is planning a major strategy session for November 6 to chart out the movement's future. Republicans are publicly criticising McCain and his campaign with increasing frequency. While some have decried his Karl Rove-like tactics, those voices have mostly come from the old guard, such as representative Chris Shays of Connecticut and Colin Powell. More are urging McCain to be more aggressive in fighting for conservative causes.

The one person on the McCain campaign who has generated excitement is Sarah Palin, who seems to already be gearing up for a 2012 run. She has been more than willing to hit Obama for "palling around with terrorists" and attack his "socialist" policy proposals. In her energy policy speech this week, Palin repeatedly veered away from her prepared remarks by substituting "our administration" for every reference to the "McCain administration".

Former House speaker and conservative revolution leader Newt Gingrich retired from Congress in 1999, but he certainly hasn't gone away quietly. In fact, he's shaping up to be a mover in the next conservative shake-up. A constant presence on Fox News, Gingrich has been a thorn in McCain's side. Gingrich has also been moulding the next generation of Republican foot soldiers in Congress, allegedly whipping up last-minute opposition to the financial bail-out package last month. (Gingrich has denied this involvement.) Additionally, Gingrich has invested considerable resources into an energy campaign urging: "Drill Here. Drill Now. Pay Less." He even appeared as a "guest star" in the GOP energy protest over the summer, which conservatives considered "America's greatest hour".

Congressmen such as Jeb Hensarling of Texas, Mike Pence of Indiana and Thaddeus McCotter of Michigan are typical of Gingrich's foot soldiers. They are intent on moving away from Bush, who decimated the Republican party, and McCain, who isn't ideological enough on issues such as immigration. The New Republic's Eve Fairbanks described this new guard as "fiercely stubborn, gutsily insubordinate, drama-loving and … unadulteratedly ideological."

A new direction doesn't necessarily mean success. Just as both Gingrich's Contract with America and Tom DeLay's infamous 1994 Republican revolution eventually failed, this new conservative direction may also find itself unable to live up to its own standards. One thing seems certain, however: Neither McCain nor Bush will be leading the way.

Barack Obama's team demonstrated its confidence of victory by today announcing it is to extend its campaign in the final days deep into the Republican heartland, adding to its target list even John McCain's home state Arizona.

While publicly warning against complacency, Obama's campaign manager, David Plouffe, told reporters today he was "thrilled" by the level of support for the Democratic candidate among the millions of ballots already cast in early voting.

"The die is being cast as we speak," said Plouffe. "We think we have built up an advantage in all the states so that Senator McCain on election day is not just going to have to carry the day, but carry it convincingly."

But McCain's camp, in defiance of Obama's poll leads and a US media that has all but written him off, claimed he was on the verge of springing a surprise result.

"We're pretty jazzed up about what were seeing, and the movement in this election," his campaign manager, Rick Davis, told a reporters' conference call. "We are witnessing, I believe, one of the greatest comebacks since John McCain won the primary."

With strong Democratic turnout in early voting, Obama's team now expects to hold all the states that John Kerry won in 2004 and add Republican states from Colorado to Virginia.

Rima and Tareef Nashashibi must be the most intriguing siblings in politics. Migrants to the United States from Palestine, they both love America, civil liberties and apple pie. They are both highly significant political figures in their home state of California, and devote all of their free time to campaigning. The difference however, is that whilst Rima is a Democrat, her brother is a staunch Republican.

"It's just our make-up and the paths we've taken," said Tareef. "I started out a small businessman, she was always an activist with causes, so the Democrats were the best fit for her. The older I got, the more conservative I became. I think having children changes you."

When you ask Rima why her views are so different to her brother's she takes a deep breath. "Seriously", she says in a sombre tone, "He was dropped on his head as a baby."

In next month's presidential election, the majority of America's 2.4 million Muslims are likely to vote with Rima rather than Tareef.

A survey carried out by the Pew Research Centre last year found that 63% of American Muslims identify with the Democrats as compared with 11% for Republicans.

The votes of Arab Muslims however, are less difficult to predict.

This group, which makes up one quarter of America's total Muslim population, tends to be more conservative than their black and Asian counterparts. In Rima and Tareef's home of Orange county, the Arab Muslim population has helped sustain Republican rule.

"Arabs are often socially conservative and successful in business, so they tend to assume they are Republican," said Rima. "But they never look up the fine print of what that means."

Tareef might not look like a traditional Republican, but his values are totally in tune with the party. As a highly paid manager in a construction firm, Tareef says he finds the small government, low tax and anti-union policies of the right attractive because they suit his business. He also says he is "automatically drawn in" by the social values of the party - family, order, patriotism - on account of his ethnicity.

Rima also has a high-flying career. In between her duties as the vice chair of the Democratic Party for Orange County, she holds down a day job at American International Group (AIG).

So why is Rima - given that she is an Arab-Muslim property owner who helps manage an investment bank - not also voting for the right? "If I were to follow the herd I'd be a Republican, but you have to be socially responsible," she said. "In truth it's got nothing to do with my background - the Democrats are simply a party for people who believe in good jobs, good education and a balanced budget."

Although both Rima and Tareef admit that their political beliefs are often a source of conflict, they insist that politics has never got in the way of their close personal relationship. Rima – who doesn't have children of her own - moved from Seal Beach to Laguna Hills to be closer to her brother and his family.

She can regularly be found at Tareef's house indulging in some of his Arabic cooking, "I know where my bread is buttered, know what I'm saying?" she says with a chuckle, "Of course we have heated arguments over dinner - I rub his nose in the last hardcore Republican that's converted to the Democrats - but it's friendly competition and sibling rivalry at its best. We never let politics get in the way. Family comes first."

In fact at times, the ideological split between Rima and Tareef doesn't so much feel like a hostile dividing line, but an affectionate bond that brings them closer together – they are like two peas in a politically confused pod.

Perhaps their most amusing collaborative endeavour is their joint stand-up comedy routine You the Republican, Me the Democrat, which raised $120,000 for the Middle East Student Initiative earlier this year. In these entirely improvised shows, Tareef stands at the podium whilst Rima wonders about the audience heckling him from a cordless mike.

"It just comes out spontaneously," said Rima. "He'll say something like 'You might be a Democrat Sis but we're still in Orange county!' and I'll say 'Yeah right – but have you looked at the electoral register recently?'"

Rima's jibe hits home. In Orange county and elsewhere, the Republican's traditional base of Arab-Muslim support has been slowly slipping away under the policies pursued by President Bush since 9/11.

According to Pew's research, 71% of Muslims who describe themselves as conservative say they now disapprove of Bush's performance. The terrorism-driven clamp down on civil liberties at home and the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan abroad have tested the loyalty of some of the party's most devout Arab supporters.

"The fine print of what it means to be a Republican is coming to the surface and the community is starting to change," said Rima. "Obama's victory shows that people are sick of the status quo – we can win this election."

For once Tareef agrees with his sister, admitting that it has become harder to hold his head up as a Republican in the Muslim community. "People ask me how I can still be a member and I say I chose the party because of its ideals, not because of its presidency," he said.

"In the past the Republican party was the leader of ethnic outreach. But then the neo-cons came and the Republicans have fallen behind. Of course it can be changed if the right people come along, but I don't think McCain will make any difference. He has deep-seated issues with the Arab world."

Rima notes with a smile, "My brother is more of a Democrat than he thinks."

Since 9/11 Rima and Tareef have found their political beliefs steadily moving closer together. It started in 2002 when the Bush administration brought in "special registration". Introduced in reaction to the terrorist attacks, this legislation required every Arab male over 16 to register with the government. Failing to register or produce legal documentation was grounds for deportation. No other migrant communities were subject to these procedures.

"It was a flashback to the regressive regimes many people left to pursue the American dream," said Rima. "Stereotyping, discrimination – it was the worst kind of racial profiling."

Both siblings opposed the proposals, "Rima would lobby the Democrats and I would lobby the Republicans," said Tareef. "When we speak on record together, people know we are speaking on behalf of the whole community because both parties are represented."

The siblings continued to work in coalition when the Iraq war started in 2003, sharing political contacts and organising joint community meetings.

"Most Republicans were so gung-ho about supporting the war I felt like a traitor for opposing it," said Tareef, "but the whole public basis for the war was lies and misconceptions."

"I've lived in the Middle East so I saw things through a different filter. I knew that Iraq and Afghanistan would never let a foreign power control them, and everything we warned about came true."

It was shortly after the Iraq war started that Tareef significantly scaled down his role in the Republican party, ending his presidency of the Arab American Club for Orange County in 2004 and stepping down from the state's central committee in 2006.

Although he cites health reasons and other priorities, he admits that Iraq, "along with the whole neo-con agenda" played some part in his decision to reduce his Republican commitments. Yet he refuses to hand in his membership. "If I leave then no one will listen to me," he said, "If you join a party and you disagree with a particular policy you have a democratic way of changing that. You have to be part of the system if you want it to change."

Children of a Palestinian family, Rima and Tareef were born and raised in Jerusalem. The Nashashibis have always been a political clan; their father was a co-founder of the Palestinian National Liberation League, and met the brother of his future wife whilst defending the city of Jerusalem in 1948.

"My father always encouraged my political activism as much as he did my brothers," said Rima, "Politics is in our blood as Palestinians and as Nashashibis."

The family moved to Orange county in 1980, but Rima regularly returns to her homeland, and in 2005 was sent by the state department to help run campaigning workshops for Palestinian women in the run up to the national elections. "I felt kinship with the people I was working with" she said, "We are one people, whether we are in the diaspora or the occupied territories. A lot of them want me to move back, but I know that staying in the States is the best way to help them. The real decisions are made here."

Although Rima is convinced that Obama would offer more hope for Palestinians than McCain, she is not unrealistic about the Democrats' potential for achieving peace in the Middle East, "If we're working on the same principles of Oslo and Madrid then anything we produce is going to be a band aid and not address the real cause of the problem," she said.

"I love the party but I don't love it blindly. The obligation is on us to educate party decisions."

Tareef, who also remains highly conscious of his roots, is equally sceptical of both parties' commitments to help his homeland.

"Foreign policy on this issue doesn't really change regardless of whether the government is Republican or Democrat. It depends who you are talking to – there are different personal, not party, platforms."

Irrespective of their political differences, Rima and Tareef both want change. At the moment, only Obama seems to be offering it.

The country will have to wait and see whether the Democrats' platform is enough to attract the disaffected Arab vote from its traditional Republican base.

Tareef's two children, Mufeed and Rasha, diplomatically keep their emerging political opinions to themselves. Whether they'll grow up to support Daddy's Republicans or Aunty's Democrats is not yet known.

Roger Hood and Carolyn Hoyle's extraordinary and painstaking new edition of The Death Penalty: A Worldwide Perspective has just landed on my desk. Now in its fourth edition, it has been some six years since the last edition appeared and since then 16 countries have completely abolished capital punishment and the number that have executed anyone within the past 10 years has fallen by a quarter – from 71 to 51 by the end of 2007.

One of those countries which continues to use capital punishment is the United States, and Hood and Hoyle's book had gone to print before the presidential campaign got into full swing, and before the supreme court ruled in Kennedy v Louisiana in June 2008 – a decision which outlawed the use of the death penalty in cases where offenders had raped children. That made me start to wonder where Obama stood on the death penalty – given that McCain has said repeatedly in the past that he is in favour, and what an incoming Obama administration might do in relation to the United States being the last western democracy to use capital punishment.

A quick look at Obama's previous public statements on capital punishment shows a certain amount of what can only be described as "trimming". In other words, his position seems to have been trimmed to better suit the reality that he has moved from community activist to presidential candidate. So, while he was at one stage against the death penalty – he argued that it did little to deter crime, in a country that is 65% behind maintaining capital punishment he has now positioned himself to support capital punishment in cases which "the community is justified in expressing the full measure of its outrage". In short, he wants it in those situations which Professor Robert Blecker of New York University would describe as "the worst of the worse".

Some indication of what this means in practice – both in terms of what is meant by the "worst of the worse", and in relation to what Obama might actually do in office – can be measured in his response to the Supreme Court's ruling on Kennedy v Louisiana. By all stretches of the imagination Patrick Kennedy's aggravated rape of his eight year old stepdaughter in March 1998 was horrific and repulsive. So great was his stepdaughter's injuries that a laceration to the left wall of her vagina had separated her cervix from the back of her vagina, which caused her rectum to protrude into the vaginal structure. Kennedy was sentenced to death given the age of his stepdaughter when he was found guilty of aggravated rape.

The supreme court ruled that this sentence was unconstitutional four months ago – in effect ruling that the death penalty could only be used when another's life had been taken - and thereby forcing Obama to reveal his hand. In response he stated that he opposed what the supreme court had done and argued that "I think that the rape of a small child, six or eight years old, is a heinous crime and if a state makes a decision that under narrow, limited, well-defined circumstances the death penalty is at least potentially applicable, that does not violate our constitution." In other words there was no way that Obama was going to be "soft on crime", and in the American context that means he is going to support capital punishment.

Of course as a skilled, liberal lawyer, Obama gave himself room to manoeuvre here and the phrase "at least potentially applicable" is open enough to interpretation to allow death penalty abolitionists to continue to give their support to Obama. And after all, unlike governor Bill Clinton, he hasn't left the campaign trail to return to Little Rock so as to sign the death warrant of a mentally retarded man on death row in Arkansas. However, the big test for Obama should he be elected – which looks likely – will be how he deals with the supreme court. Specifically how he replaces two supreme court judges who for one reason or another are likely to step down during his first term in office – 88-year old John Paul Stevens (a liberal on death penalty cases despite being a Republican nominee) and Ruth Bader Ginsburg who is in her seventies and has been ill with cancer. Finding replacements for Stevens and Ginsberg will tilt and colour the dynamics of the supreme court as President Obama sees fit, and if he really does want the United States to "lead the world" he should be mindful that every western democratic legal jurisdiction has its own appalling crimes to deal with and that we have all managed to cope without resorting to capital punishment.

Barack Obama's campaign has dropped three US newspapers from its travelling plane in the final days of the election, drawing fire from conservatives who see a pattern: all three have endorsed John McCain.

Reporters from the Washington Times, the Rupert Murdoch-owned New York Post, and the Dallas Morning News were told last night that space had run out on Obama's plane for his final campaign swing.

The conservative-leaning Drudge Report website fuelled the story today by suggesting that the newspapers were frozen out because their editorial pages have endorsed McCain. The Washington Times added to the controversy by publishing a story criticising its exclusion.

"This feels like the journalistic equivalent of redistributing the wealth," Times executive editor John Solomon said - echoing the McCain camp's recent attacks on Obama for suggesting that tax policy should help "share the wealth".

"[W]e spent hundreds of thousands of dollars covering Senator Obama's campaign, travelling on his plane, and taking our turn in the reporter's pool," Solomon added, "only to have our seat given away to someone else in the last days of the campaign."

Although the Times and Post are considered conservative media outlets, the US press traditionally maintains strict separation between editorials and news coverage. In an email quoted by the Times, the Obama camp said the exclusion of the three newspapers was prompted by dwindling space, not ideology.

"Unfortunately, demand for seats on the plane during this final weekend has far exceeded supply," Anita Dunn, a senior Obama adviser, wrote.

"This means we've had to make hard, and unpleasant for all concerned, decisions about limiting some news organizations and in some cases not being in a position to offer space to news organisations altogether."

The McCain campaign has had its own share of controversial ejections from its travelling media corps this year. Joe Klein of Time magazine and Maureen Dowd of the New York Times, both liberal-leaning columnists, have been barred from the McCain press circuit after publishing articles critical of the Republican nominee.

With less than 100 hours to go before election day, Barack Obama and John McCain are using Halloween to kick off a final sprint through battleground states, trotting out tricks and treats to woo undecided voters.

Obama's schedule is the more dizzying. The Democratic nominee begins his day in Iowa – the site of his first primary triumph 10 months ago – before moving on to Indiana and Nevada.

McCain, meanwhile, is completing a bus tour through Ohio, the state he is increasingly pinning his hopes on as polls show Obama holding on to a lead in most of the key battlegrounds.

"I'm confident we'll win [in Ohio]," the Republican candidate told ABC News this morning. The Californian governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, will be by McCain's side today in that crucial state.

In America's other perennial swing state, Florida, there is no lack of political players. Al Gore will return today to the site where his presidential dreams died, campaigning for Obama in the south Florida counties where the voting recount occurred in 2000.

Hillary Clinton will pick up Gore's baton tomorrow, appearing on Obama's behalf in Miami and Orlando, Florida. Bill Clinton will campaign in West Virginia and New Hampshire.

The goal of this furious pace is not only to court still-vulnerable voters but also to attract national attention at a time when the media has largely ceased covering policy in order to focus on the election map.

Obama is well positioned to project an aura of confidence as he traipses through states George Bush won easily in 2000 and 2004, while McCain cannot even take his home state of Arizona for granted – he has started running automated phone calls there attacking Obama as unprepared.

Despite the recent wave of bad news for McCain, two bright spots emerged for him this morning: Missouri and North Carolina. A poll released today by Politico.com found the race neck and neck in both states, a tightening from earlier surveys that had found Obama slightly ahead.

It's hard to believe, I know, but the McCain campaign seems intent on delving further and further into the gutter in its desperate attempt to tar Barack Obama with something - anything - that will undermine the trust he's earned from voters for the past two years. The most recent episode involves a full-court press in speeches and interviews by both candidates and their surrogates to inspire yet another McCarthyite panic, this one among Jews (especially those in Florida, no doubt).

To review, five years ago Barack Obama spoke at the same dinner as Rashid Khalidi, a noted scholar and current professor at Columbia University. There were some harsh things said by others at the dinner, but not by Khalidi or Obama. Obama "called for finding common ground" in his remarks and said that his commitment to Israel's security is "nonnegotiable", according to the Los Angeles Times, which wrote an extensive account of the dinner six months ago. The reporter, Peter Wallsten, based that story on a videotape of the dinner, which was provided to him by a source on the condition that it not be released.

Now right-wingers are demanding that the tape be released. "A major news organisation is intentionally suppressing information that could provide a clearer link between Barack Obama and Rashid Khalidi," said McCain campaign spokesman Michael Goldfarb. "The election is one week away, and it's unfortunate that the press so obviously favours Barack Obama that this campaign must publicly request that the Los Angeles Times do its job - make information public." Sarah Palin, on the stump in Ohio on Wednesday, said: "Among other things, Israel was described there as the perpetrator of terrorism rather than the victim. What we don't know is how Barack Obama responded to these slurs on a country that he professes to support." (Note: professes to support).

McCain, sans any evidence whatsoever, claims that, hey, maybe William Ayers was there too. He told Larry King on Wednesday: "I still think, you know, we're watching now, a major newspaper has a tape that apparently has Mr William Ayers in it. I don't know if it does or not. That's the allegation. But that newspaper and their parent, the Tribune Company, and the Obama campaign refuse to release that. Shouldn't the American people know about that? At least they should have full information." There's even a protest outside the LA Times.

This pathetic effort should, in a normal world, be laughed off the airwaves and news pages. First and most importantly, Khalidi is not someone that anyone should be ashamed to know. He is a noted and well-respected Palestinian scholar. Michael Hudson, director of the Centre for Contemporary Arab Studies at Georgetown, describes Khalidi as pre-eminent in his field, a courageous scholar and public figure. John McCain apparently thought so too at one point, since the International Republican Institute, with McCain at the helm, gave Khalidi's Centre for Palestine Research and Studies a $448,000 grant in the late 1990s.

No concrete offence of Khalidi's has actually been alleged, so far as I'm aware, except that he once served as spokesman for the PLO, which Khalidi denies. Still, McCain made this stunning comparison on Wednesday: "If there was a tape of John McCain in a neo-Nazi outfit, I think the treatment of the issue would be slightly different," he said in an interview with Hispanic radio stations.

This modern-day McCarthyism seems to rely much more on the fact that Rashid Khalidi's name is Rashid Khalidi than any concrete allegations of wrongdoing. And the haphazard insinuation that maybe Ayers was there too is a transparent attempt to bait the Times into releasing the tape. The McCain people must know that a journalist cannot and will not burn a source. "The Los Angeles Times did not publish the videotape because it was provided to us by a confidential source who did so on the condition that we not release it," said the newspaper's editor, Russ Stanton. "The Times keeps its promises to sources."

Perhaps Sarah Palin is actually ignorant enough about journalism to believe the foolish charge she utters when complaining: "It must be nice for a candidate to have major news organisations looking out for their best interests like that. Politicians would love to have a pet newspaper of their very own." But surely Goldfarb, who left the Weekly Standard to join McCain's campaign, knows better, and is playing the dim bulb for purely political purposes. (All this will no doubt keep him in good standing with his colleagues at the Standard, alas.)

Sadly, the media has been more than happy to provide that noise. "Sen John McCain … continued to criticize the radical professors with whom Sen Barack Obama … has associations," explained ABC's Jake Tapper, simply assuming that Khalidi fit this description without any apparent familiarity with his work. "McCain attacked Obama for associating with both William Ayers and Rashid Khalidi on CNN's Larry King Live tonight."

In King's conversation with McCain, he too, bought into the crazy notion that the LA Times was somehow suppressing the news that the newspaper, alone, had reported. Last night on CNN, Anderson Cooper summed up the MSM attitude perfectly: "McCain and Palin are making a big deal about this Palestinian-American professor. We don't take sides on this programme. We just want the facts, so we asked Tom Foreman to look into this guy and allegations of a relationship with Obama and McCain."

A long package ensued. The only sensible perspective provided by CNN last night was this, from Dana Bash: "When I asked the McCain aide why they are just now bringing up a six-month-old article about a dinner five years ago, the aide was strikingly candid. He said - quote - 'Because Obama may be one week away from being elected president.'"

Really, one shudders for the fate of the free world when one considers the combination of stupidity, tastelessness, bigotry and outright idiocy that lies at the centre of this appeal.

John Lewis suffered a 9.8% fall in sales at its department stores last week compared with a year ago, and warned of a "testing Christmas" as the economic downturn gathers pace.

The earlier timing of last year's school half-term may have affected the figure to last Saturday, but John Lewis said it was clear that customers were being "far more judicious" in their spending in the face of recession.

Singer analyst Matthew McEachran said the figures implied sales declines in the "high teens" on a same-store basis. Sales at the group's upmarket food chain, Waitrose, edged up 0.6% in the week to October 25, a figure which he said implied a like-for-like decline.

All categories were down at John Lewis department stores, in particular sales of items for the home, which fell 17.3%, and electrical goods, down 9.6%. Fashion sales dropped by 1.3%.

Northern stores outperformed the south, where Milton Keynes, Cribbs Causeway near Bristol, Southampton and Watford suffered sales falls of more than 20%. Growth at the John Lewis website slowed to 7.8% from 24%.

"The third quarter of the year ended on a subdued note, coinciding as it did with confirmation that the UK economy shrank during this period," said Andy Street, John Lewis's managing director. "The effect can clearly be seen in our trade – with a distinct softening since the summer."

With 55 days to go until Christmas, Street said: "For sure, it is going to be a testing Christmas, but our readiness is second to none."

Retail analyst Freddie George at Seymour Pierce said John Lewis would have been affected by the timing of half term and discounting at a number of competitors, including Debenhams, House of Fraser and Bhs. "We understand that sales have strongly recovered in the current week," he said.

However, George has slashed his profit estimates for Marks & Spencer and today, Ted Baker, "predominantly because we are concerned about the medium-term outlook, the impact of the downturn on high spending urban shoppers and an increase in the level of discount activity". He warned that next year would be even bleaker for retailers.

Given that John Lewis department store sales are seen as a bellwether for the health of consumer spending, Howard Archer at Global Insight described the plunge in last week's sales as "extremely worrying". "This heightens fears that the economy will suffer from an extended period of serious consumer retrenchment. I'm trying to understand the tremendous furore in Britain over Russell Brand and Jonathan Ross' lewd performance on the BBC. Really, I am.

But for those of us on the other side of the Atlantic, can someone please explain why this uproar has commenced over offending an actor who became famous by offensively caricaturing Hispanics as uneducated (and worthy of beatings)? Seriously, the difference between the BBC's envelope-pushing humour of the 1970s and its envelope-pushing humour of today comes down to John Cleese being funnier than Russell Brand.

If the true source of outrage over the Brand-Ross phone calls comes from concern over the BBC's use of its license fees from the public, then the brouhaha makes more sense.

Requiring households to support a sprawling broadcast empire is hardly a mainstream notion in America, as the frequent battles over our (profanity-free) public television demonstrate. But I can certainly share in the scepticism over treating questionable public investments as sacred ground. After all, how can John McCain continue to hammer at Barack Obama for not taking taxpayer money for his campaign? Since when is it a bad thing to spare the public a dubious bill for lame jokes about Britney and Moses?

But it seems the row cuts deeper than even the BBC, as Britons ask themselves whether the character of their culture has been irreversibly debased. The answer, indisputably, is no. Monty Python's best routines are more indecorous than Brand and Ross' silly cracks about a grandfather despairing that his little grandaughter enjoys sex – think Mr Creosote or Brian breaking into song during his crucifixion. But, again, the only crime the BBC hosts committed was attempting far inferior offensive comedy.

In a world where 82-year-old Cloris Leachman becomes the shock hit of a reality TV dancing show, where an 80-year-old exotic dancer can still strut her stuff, and where Sean Connery remains a sex symbol at the same age as Sachs, why is it unconscionable for a couple of comedians to rib an older man about the dirty deed? Given that Brand has been confirmed as an ex-lover of the granddaughter whose virtue was impugned in this case, is it any more beyond the pale than the 2006 film that imagined the assassination of George Bush?

Please, let's move on to a more meaningful debate about media - the death knell of print journalism heralded this week by the Christian Science Monitor, perhaps? Bollocks. If we're looking for a good ruckus over humour and offence, let's talk about whether the "sexism" chargethrown at Tina Fey's Sarah Palin imitation is, in itself, insulting.

Oh no. Now that there's profanity in this comment piece, I certainly can't send it to my grandmother.

Representing the City and East constituency, John Biggs has a particular responsibility towards some of London's least affluent citizens. His various Assembly duties include chairing the Budget and Performance Committee and needling Mayor Johnson at question time.

The economic situation is creating great uncertainty for us in London. While there has rightly been much written about financial services job cuts, I suspect the bigger impact will be on those that support the financial sector, wider business support and the leisure and tourism industries. Another very visible casualty will undoubtedly be the construction sector, with house builders closing down building sites across the city as the market for buyers seizes up and prices slip.
It would be easy to view the downturn as primarily affecting the middle classes. But this is by no means the whole picture. As an elected representative for some of London's poorest citizens, I am acutely aware that those at the bottom will be squeezed the hardest - whether it is those in low paid service economy jobs, or construction, or those who are looking for a decent home but are unable to compete in the market place. So what should we do? It is early days yet but not too early to think about the future. Although London has been written-off by many as a manufacturing location, the reality is that the sector has been so battered for decades that what remains, provided there is demand for its products, is quite strong and battle-hardened. If financial services are struggling, sectors like manufacturing may take some of the strain. As regards construction I would argue that this is just the right time for public investment to meet needs and to stimulate activity in the construction industry and the market place - so a major programme of house building and infrastructure projects would be a very good idea.

We need also, and we should never tire of this, to emphasise that in an open economy like London/the UK, investment in skills and infrastructure are vital if we are to hold our own against growing competition. So I would renew the emphasis on skills training, and lobby hard for investment in projects like Crossrail and the Olympic legacy, and housing. These are uncertain and difficult times but we should not be deterred from investing in London's future.
So what does this mean for our Mayor, Boris Johnson? In tough times politicians like to bury their differences but, conversely, their differences become all the more important. Boris has made some of the right noises, especially on the need deliver Crossrail. But on housing, for example, he seems to be stuck in an ideological cul de sac. The next few months will be a big test for the Mayor. We will soon see just how much of London he understands and just how committed he is to its needs.

After attending the jubilant homecoming service and dinner at Cincinnati's Rockdale Baptist Church, we paid a visit to Marian A Spencer, an 88-year-old activist and leader in the city's African American community.

Dressed in her Sunday finery, she brought us into her home, where she had gathered together a small group of women friends, who lost no time in getting down to brass tacks.

When one woman pointedly said Obama's candidacy was not a matter of colour but of character and ability, others sharply disagreed. Race, they insisted, was still a central issue in the election, and in US politics and society.

They could hardly believe they were on the verge of seeing an African American elected president - and they knew that an Obama victory would not mean that the struggle for equality was over. They were realistic, even sceptical, of what lay ahead.

The women's scepticism is borne out by the election itself: even with a black man on the ballot, African American voters continue to face barriers at the polls, as they have to one degree or another throughout US history.

Black men may have obtained the constitutional right to vote following the civil war, followed by black and white women in 1920. But especially in the south, African Americans, along with other minorities and poor people of all races, were kept from voting through other means, including poll taxes, literacy tests, and restrictive registration procedures.

While formal poll taxes were declared illegal in 1965 with the passage of the Voting Rights Act, versions of it remain in place - for instance, in the cost of taking time off work, travelling to the polls, or obtaining identification.

African American votes are now discounted by many other means, as well. In Florida in 2000, the suppression of black votes changed the final outcome of the presidential election. The US Commission on Civil Rights found "widespread disenfranchisement and denial of voting rights" in Florida, which was ten times more likely to affect African Americans.

More than 57,000 voters were "purged" from the voting rolls as supposed felons; over half were black, and more than 90% were innocent. In addition, the report found, thousands of eligible African Americans were turned away because their registration forms had never been processed, and thousands more had their votes tossed out on account of "spoilage" rendered by the "antiquated and error-prone equipment" more likely to be found in poor and minority areas. In 2000, the spoilage rate for black votes in Florida was 14.4%, or one in seven; for white votes it was 1.6%.

In 2004, some of the worst cases of vote suppression took place here in Ohio, where voters who were non-white, poor, young, or newly registered were far more likely to find their names expunged from the voting rolls, or to face four and five-hour waits at polling stations.

This year, in a case that went all the way to the US supreme court, Ohio's Democratic secretary of state, Jennifer Brunner, refused to turn over to the state Republican party a list of 200,000 newly registered voters whose information did not precisely match information on other government databases.

Since these first-time voters clearly favour Obama, Republicans are seeking to purge as many as possible from the voting rolls by turning what are clearly innocent discrepancies into trumped-up evidence of voter fraud.

The Ohio GOP is now running statewide ads asking, "Could Ohio's election be stolen?". Brunner has said that the Republicans are preparing the ground for challenges if Obama wins the state, hoping to "segregate and pick off ballots if it's a close race".

Like other states, Ohio has instituted early voting, hoping to cut down the long lines and chaos on election day, and increase access for people who can't get off work or have difficulty travelling to the polls.

Still, in Cuyahoga County, where Cleveland is located, problems are already beginning. Volunteers and employees of the Greater Ohio Voter Coalition have been comparing lists of the people they had registered over the last year with the database of the Board of Elections. When we spoke with them, they had already found problems with about 300 of the 3700 registrations - about 8%.

Many of these were simply missing from the system entirely. The group sends a card to the individuals with errors urging them to re-register, but fears that many of them won't make it onto the rolls by election day.

Even the seemingly most innocent aspects of the voting process cause problems. Victoria Lovegren, a computer scientist and voting rights activist in Cleveland, argues that something as simple as the pens used to fill in the ovals on the ballots - ball points, rather than the easier and quicker felt tips - may well end up causing longer lines in areas where there are already far too few polling stations to serve the population.

The overall impact of these seemingly insignificant obstacles comes down disproportionately on minorities, just as the poll taxes did a century ago.

"That's the whole shame of it," Lovegren said. "They know those are the people who are going to be affected by these decisions. It was simply heartbreaking in 2004 to see the lines of people who couldn't vote."
